words.meaning: Feeling or caused to feel embarrassed, disconcerted, or ashamed.
examples: He was clearly abashed by the praise.
She felt abashed at her own cowardice.

words.meaning: To become less intense or widespread.
examples: The storm suddenly abated.
We waited for the wind to abate before we set sail.

words.meaning: To renounce one's throne, right, power, claim, responsibility, or the like, especially in a formal manner.
examples: The king was forced to abdicate.
She abdicated all responsibility for the project.

words.meaning: Departing from an accepted standard.
examples: This aberrant behavior is not typical for him.
The aberrant cells can lead to cancer.

words.meaning: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically one that is unwelcome.
examples: They described the outbreak of violence as an aberration.
She is normally calm and level-headed, so this outburst is an aberration.

words.meaning: To encourage or assist someone to do something wrong, in particular, to commit a crime.
examples: He was abetted in the deception by his wife.
To abet a crime is a crime itself.

words.meaning: A state of temporary disuse or suspension.
examples: The project is being held in abeyance until agreement is reached on funding.
Matters were held in abeyance pending the outcome of the lawsuit.

words.meaning: To regard with disgust and hatred.
examples: I abhor all forms of racism.
She abhors violence.

words.meaning: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of abhor.
examples: He abhors any type of cruelty.
Nature abhors a vacuum.

words.meaning: To accept or act in accordance with (a rule, decision, or recommendation).
examples: I will abide by their decision.
You must abide by the rules of the game.

words.meaning: (of something bad) experienced or present to the maximum degree; or (of a person or their behavior) completely without pride or dignity; self-abasing.
examples: They live in abject poverty.
He offered an abject apology.

words.meaning: To solemnly renounce (a belief, cause, or claim).
examples: He abjured his religion.
The defendant abjured his former life of crime.

words.meaning: A thing that causes disgust or hatred.
examples: This new building is an abomination.
Cruelty to animals is an abomination.

words.meaning: Inhabiting or existing in a land from the earliest times or from before the arrival of colonists; indigenous.
examples: The aboriginal peoples of Australia have a rich culture.
They studied the aboriginal art of the region.

words.meaning: To carry out or undergo the abortion of (a fetus). or To bring to a premature end because of a problem or fault.
examples: The mission had to be aborted.
They decided to abort the launch.

words.meaning: Failing to produce the intended result.
examples: The rebels made an abortive attempt to seize power.
It was an abortive attempt to reform the system.

words.meaning: To exist in large numbers or amounts.
examples: The rivers abound with fish.
Opportunities abound in this new field.

words.meaning: Legitimate, honest, and open.
examples: All our dealings have been completely aboveboard.
We need to ensure that the process is fair and aboveboard.

words.meaning: (of a substance or material) capable of polishing or cleaning a hard surface by rubbing or grinding. or (of a person or manner) showing little concern for the feelings of others; harsh.
examples: She has a rather abrasive manner.
He can be very abrasive in meetings.

words.meaning: Side by side and facing the same way. or Up to date with the latest news, ideas, or information.
examples: The two men walked abreast down the street.
It is important to keep abreast of the latest developments.

words.meaning: To shorten (a piece of writing) without losing the sense.
examples: The book was abridged for children.
I have abridged the report.

words.meaning: To repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement).
examples: The treaty was abrogated in 1929.
A new law to abrogate the old one was passed.

words.meaning: The natural detachment of parts of a plant, typically dead leaves and ripe fruit.
examples: The abscission of leaves in the fall is a natural process.
Hormones can trigger abscission.

words.meaning: To leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to avoid detection of or arrest for an unlawful action such as theft.
examples: She absconded with the company's funds.
The suspect absconded before the police arrived.

words.meaning: Not qualified or diminished in any way; total.
examples: He is an absolute monarch.
I have absolute confidence in her.

words.meaning: To set or declare (someone) free from blame, guilt, or responsibility.
examples: The pardon absolved them of any crime.
She was absolved of all wrongdoing.

words.meaning: To restrain oneself from doing or enjoying something.
examples: I am trying to abstain from sweets.
He abstained from voting.

words.meaning: Not self-indulgent, especially when eating and drinking.
examples: He is an abstemious man.
She is abstemious in her habits.

words.meaning: The fact or practice of restraining oneself from indulging in something, typically alcohol.
examples: He is a firm believer in abstinence.
Total abstinence from alcohol is the only way for him.

words.meaning: Existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical or concrete existence.
examples: Abstract concepts such as love and hatred are difficult to define.
She is an expert in abstract art.

words.meaning: Difficult to understand; obscure.
examples: The professor's lectures were abstruse and hard to follow.
He had a taste for abstruse literature.

words.meaning: Wildly unreasonable, illogical, or inappropriate.
examples: The idea that the earth is flat is absurd.
It was an absurd suggestion.

words.meaning: Extremely bad; appalling.
examples: The quality of the food was abysmal.
His first attempt was an abysmal failure.

words.meaning: A deep or seemingly bottomless chasm.
examples: He stood at the edge of the abyss.
The country is on the edge of an economic abyss.

words.meaning: To assent or agree to a demand, request, or treaty.
examples: The government acceded to the protesters' demands.
He acceded to the throne in 1837.

words.meaning: To make more noticeable or prominent.
examples: Her dress was tightly belted, accentuating the slimness of her waist.
The new policy only serves to accentuate the existing social inequalities.

words.meaning: The means or opportunity to approach or enter a place. or To obtain, examine, or retrieve (data or a file).
examples: The only access to the village is by boat.
I can't access my email.

words.meaning: (of a place) able to be reached or entered. or (of a person, typically one in a position of authority) friendly and easy to talk to; approachable.
examples: The island is accessible only by boat.
The professor is very accessible to students.

words.meaning: The attainment or acquisition of a position of rank or power, typically that of monarch or president.
examples: The accession of Queen Victoria to the throne.
The accession of new member states to the European Union.

words.meaning: To praise enthusiastically and publicly.
examples: The book was widely acclaimed by critics.
She has won critical acclaim for her performance.

words.meaning: An award or privilege granted as a special honor or as an acknowledgment of merit.
examples: He received the highest accolade of his profession.
She has received numerous accolades for her work.

words.meaning: (of physical space, especially a building) provide lodging or sufficient space for. or To fit in with the wishes or needs of.
examples: The hotel can accommodate up to 500 guests.
We will do our best to accommodate your needs.

words.meaning: A person who helps another commit a crime.
examples: He was convicted as an accomplice to the murder.
She was an accomplice in the robbery.

words.meaning: To approach and address (someone) boldly or aggressively.
examples: He was accosted by a stranger in the street.
She was accosted by a beggar.

words.meaning: The process of growth or increase, typically by the gradual accumulation of additional layers or matter.
examples: The accretion of cosmic dust.
The accretion of wealth.

words.meaning: (of sums of money or benefits) be received by someone in regular or increasing amounts over time.
examples: Interest will accrue on the account.
The benefits of the new policy will accrue over time.

words.meaning: To gather together or acquire an increasing number or quantity of.
examples: I seem to have accumulated a lot of books.
Dust had accumulated on the furniture.

words.meaning: (especially of a comment or style of speaking) sharp and forthright.
examples: He is known for his acerbic wit.
She made an acerbic comment about his clothes.

words.meaning: A weakness or vulnerable point.
examples: His arrogance is his Achilles heel.
The team's Achilles heel is their defense.

words.meaning: To accept or admit the existence or truth of.
examples: She acknowledged that she had been at fault.
He is widely acknowledged to be the best player in the world.

words.meaning: The point at which someone or something is best, perfect, or most successful.
examples: He reached the acme of his career in the 1990s.
The acme of perfection.

words.meaning: A person assisting the celebrant in a religious service or procession. or An assistant or follower.
examples: He was a devoted acolyte of the charismatic leader.
The priest was assisted by an acolyte.

words.meaning: To accept something reluctantly but without protest.
examples: She seemed to acquiesce in the decision.
He will acquiesce to her demands.

words.meaning: Excessively interested in acquiring money or material things.
examples: We live in an acquisitive society.
He is a very acquisitive person.

words.meaning: Having an irritatingly strong and unpleasant taste or smell.
examples: Acrid smoke from the burning tires filled the air.
The acrid smell of burning rubber.

words.meaning: (typically of an argument or debate) angry and bitter.
examples: They had an acrimonious divorce.
The debate was acrimonious.

words.meaning: Bitterness or ill feeling.
examples: The dispute was settled without acrimony.
The acrimony of the campaign was evident.

words.meaning: The policy or action of using vigorous campaigning to bring about political or social change.
examples: Her activism has made a real difference.
He has a long history of political activism.

words.meaning: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions, typically in a particular domain.
examples: She has a great deal of business acumen.
He has a sharp political acumen.

words.meaning: (of a bad, difficult, or unwelcome situation or phenomenon) present or experienced to a severe or intense degree. or Having or showing a perceptive understanding or insight; shrewd.
examples: There is an acute shortage of water.
He has an acute mind.
